#Text=3.
#Text=Intercept – Resend Emulation Attacks
#Text=The emulation attacks under consideration follow closely the general theoretical framework of Ref . , which is summarized in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=.
#Text=We assume that the adversary does not have access to the preparation of the probe states , the actual PUK , the SLM , or the HD set-up .

#Text=However , he has obtained somehow a copy of all the possible CRPs to be used in the authentication of the PUK , and moreover he has obtained access to the incoming and outgoing SMFs , without being detected .

#Text=Hence , if the adversary were able to estimate exactly the probe state , he would be able to impersonate successfully the holder of the PUK , by looking at the CRPs and by sending to the HD set-up the expected response state .
#Text=However , quantum physics does not allow for perfect discrimination between non-orthogonal quantum states , or the measurement of non-communting quantum observables with arbitrary accuracy .
#Text=As a result , it is inevitable for the adversary ’s intervention to introduce errors in the HD performed by the verifier .

#Text=Given that the probe states in the M queries are chosen at random and independently from a uniform distribution over the set , from now on , we can focus on one of the queries and let denote the incoming probe state .
#Text=The adversary ’s task is to obtain an estimate of the integer k , which determines fully the challenge and the expected response .
#Text=To this end , he performs a measurement on the incoming probe state , and , based on the outcome , the adversary makes an educated guess about k , to be denoted by .

#Text=For the reasons discussed above , this guess may or may not be equal to the actual k used by the verifier , and thus the adversary ’s intervention will affect the probability with which the verifier obtains an outcome in the expected bin .
#Text=More precisely , instead of Equation ( 3 ) , one has ( 4a ) where and denote the -quadratures of the response field , when the adversary deduces the correct and the wrong value of k .
#Text=Both of them are given by Equation ( 2 ) for k and , respectively .

#Text=Given that the verifier samples from both quadratures at random and independently , after M queries , the verifier will obtain an estimate of the average probability ( 4b ) where is given by Equation ( 4a ) and ( 5 ) is the probability for the adversary to make an error in his estimation of k .
#Text=The probability takes into account all of the events irrespective of whether the adversary deduced the correct value of k or not .
#Text=In the second equality of Equation ( 4b ) , we have taken into account the uniform distribution of k over and of over .
#Text=Moreover , we have used the fact that the state of the probe and the outcome of the adversary are independent of the quadrature to be measured by the verifier .

#Text=A straightforward calculation shows that is always smaller than the corresponding expression in the absence of cheating [ which is given by Equation ( 3 ) ] , and the difference ( 6a ) basically quantifies the adversary ’s intervention .
#Text=The adversary ’s intervention will be detected by the verifier when the observed deviations from exceed the statistical deviations i.e. , when ( 6b )
